facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 309 and 525 of 59 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 309 and 525 of 59.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and orders dated August 27, 1958, November 24, 1958, and March 10, 1958 of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders and decree dated August 27, 1958, November 24, 1958, and March 10, 1958 of the Calcutta High Court,

facts.text: In Award Case No. 103 of 1955 and Appeal from Original Order No. 26 of 1956 in Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: in Award Case No. 103 of 1955 and Appeal from Original order No. 26 of 1956 respectively.

facts.text: Contract entered into between the parties for supply of gunny sacks on August 29, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: These facts are that a companytract was entered into between the parties for supply of companysacks on August 29, 1951.

facts.text: Contract contained an arbitration clause referring disputes to Bengal Chamber of Commerce.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract companytained an arbitration clause in the following terms All matters, questions, disputes, difference and or claims arising out of and or companycerning and or in companynection with and or in companysequence of or relating to this companytract...

facts.text: Disputes arose with respect to carrying out of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose with respect to carrying out of the companytract and on October 25, 1951,

facts.text: Respondent referred disputes to arbitration of Bengal Chamber of Commerce on October 25, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent referred these disputes to the arbitration of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce  hereinafter referred to as the Chamber . That case was numbered 217 of 1951 in the Chambers records.

facts.text: Case numbered 217 of 1951 in Chamber's records.

anchor.surface_text: That case was numbered 217 of 1951 in the Chambers records.

facts.text: Tribunal of Arbitration made an award disallowing the claim of the respondent on April 17, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On April 17, 1952, the tribunal of Arbitration made an award disallowing the claim of the respondent.

facts.text: Award filed in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This award was filed in the High Court.

facts.text: Award set aside on May 25, 1953 by learned Single Judge on ground of misconduct of arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: On May 25, 1953, the award was set aside on the ground of misconduct on the part of the arbitrators by a learned Single Judge.

facts.text: Order setting aside award taken in appeal and dismissed on July 8, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: That order was taken in appeal and on July 8, 1954 L the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Leave to appeal to Supreme Court refused.

anchor.surface_text: Later, leave to appeal to this Court was refused and thus the order of the learned Single Judge setting aside the award finally stood.

facts.text: Respondent addressed letter to Chamber on September 7, 1953 referring matter for arbitration de novo.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after the award had been set aside by the learned Single Judge, the respondent addressed a letter to the Chamber on September 7, 1953.

facts.text: Another tribunal constituted under rules of Chamber to decide dispute afresh.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon another tribunal was companystituted under the rules of the Chamber to decide the dispute afresh.

facts.text: Appellant appeared before tribunal and contended no jurisdiction for second reference.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appeared before the tribunal and companytended that it had numberjurisdiction to make an award on a second references in the same dispute.

facts.text: Tribunal made award on March 15, 1955 in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal, however, proceeded to decide the reference and made the award on March 15, 1955. This time the award was in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court on August 4, 1955 to set aside award or supersede arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon on August 4, 1955, the appellant made an application to the High Court praying that the award be set aside.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge dismissed application relying on Barangore Jute Factory case.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant came to this Court for special leave, which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Supreme Court on December 12, 1961 by Wanchoo J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. December 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-

facts.text: In appeal 525, appellant objected to appointment of fresh tribunal and applied under s.33.

anchor.surface_text: Turning number to appeal No. 525, it is enough to say that it is similar to appeal No. 309 in all respects except one.

facts.text: In appeal 525, Single Judge allowed application and revoked authority of Chamber.

anchor.surface_text: What happened in this case was that the learned Single Judge allowed the application and revoked the authority of the Chamber to arbitrate.

facts.text: Appeal against Single Judge order allowed by High Court relying on Barangore case.

anchor.surface_text: There was then an appeal by the present respondent which was allowed on the basis of the Barangore Jute Factory case  1 .

issues.text: Whether, after the first award was set aside without superseding the reference under s.19 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, the reference was exhausted, the arbitrator functus officio, and further arbitration on the same dispute not possible without a fresh agreement, irrespective of whether the letter of September 7, 1953 amounted to a second reference or continuation of the original.

anchor.surface_text: The main question that has been argued before us is that the first award was set aside on May 25, 1953, the reference was exhausted and the arbitrator had become functus officio and it was therefore not possible without a fresh arbitration agreement to have the same dispute decided again by the arbitrator, irrespective of whether the letter of September 7, 1953, amounted to a second reference or was a mere request for continuation of the proceedings in the original reference, which had proved abortive as the award originally made had been set aside.

issues.text: Whether there is machinery under the rules of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce (Rules V, VII, X) for constituting a new arbitral tribunal to continue or decide afresh the same dispute after the earlier tribunal's award is set aside for misconduct, without supersession of the reference.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the rules of the Chamber relating to the appointment of arbitral tribunal. It is urged on behalf of the appellant that there is no provision in these rules for appointment of an arbitral tribunal where an award made by an earlier tribunal is set aside say, for misconduct. If this contention is a justified it will certainly not be possible to appoint another arbitral tribunal to decide the reference after the award made on it by the earlier tribunal set aside.

issues.text: Whether there was misconduct by the second tribunal justifying setting aside of the second award dated March 15, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge then went into the question whether there was such misconduct as would justify setting aside the award and held that there were no grounds made out which would justify the setting aside of the award. Consequently, the application for setting aside the award was dismissed.

issues.text: Whether an application under s.33 of the Arbitration Act challenging the existence of arbitration agreement post-set aside award (without supersession) is maintainable, and whether the order thereon is appealable under s.39 or Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: It has been contended on behalf of the appellant that the order under s. 33 was not appealable in view of the provisions of s. 39 of the Act and therefore the High Court had no jurisdiction in appeal to set aside the order of the learned Single Judge. This point as to jurisdiction was not taken before the appeal court nor has it been taken in the special leave petition to this Court or in the statement of case.

holdings.text: Where an award is set aside under the Arbitration Act, 1940, the court has discretion under s.19 to supersede the reference or not; if not superseded, the reference and arbitration agreement continue to subsist with respect to the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 reads as follows- Where an award has become void under sub-section 3  of section 16 or has been set aside, the court may by order supersede the reference and shall thereupon order that the arbitration agreement shall cease to have effect with respect to the difference referred. Before we consider what s. 19 provides we might advert to two matters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Chap II ss.3-19; contrast with prior CPC Sch II para15(2) mandatory supersession and English Act absence; discretion depends on arbitration agreement nature.

holdings.text: The contention that after setting aside the first award without supersession, the arbitrator is functus officio preventing further arbitration on the same dispute without fresh agreement is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to see however are the scheme and the provisions of the Arbitration Act, No. X of 1940  hereinafter called the Act , which govern the proceedings in arbitration in this case. These provisions are to be found in Chap. II of the Act which deal with arbitration without intervention of Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19 discretion; ss.13(d),16 allow post-award actions; distinguishes English cases like Russel, Mordues; reference survives if not superseded.

holdings.text: Functus officio after award is not absolute; arbitrator/court can take further action under ss.13(d),16,19 without changing award substance.

anchor.surface_text: We have already said that generally speaking, the arbitrator becomes functus officio after he has given the award but that does not in our opinion mean that in no circumstances

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provisions permit corrections, remittal, non-supersession; general principle limited.

holdings.text: The arbitration clause is wide in amplitude, contemplating references of disputes as they arise, allowing another tribunal under Chamber rules if reference subsists.

anchor.surface_text: We have already set out the term in the contract relating to arbitration and it is clear that term is very wide in its amplitude and contemplates reference of disputes as and when

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of clause referring all disputes to Chamber under its rules.

holdings.text: The letter dated September 7, 1953 does not constitute a second reference but a request to continue the original subsisting reference after award set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Stress in this connection has been laid on the letter of September 7, 1953, in which the respondent said that it begged to refer the matter for arbitration de novo. Those words do not in our opinion show that a second reference

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual reading: 'de novo' means take up again post-set aside; not fresh dispute.

holdings.text: Rule V(2) applies only to initial tribunal constitution on first application, not after award set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Rule V 1  provides for an application for arbitration. Rule V 2  lays down that on receipt of such application the Registrar shall constitute a court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text limits to first receipt of application; prior use already exhausted.

holdings.text: Rule VII applies only where tribunal allows time/extended time to expire without award, not where award made then set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Rule VII says that if the Court have allowed the time or extended time to expire without making any award, and without having signified to the Registrar that they cannot agree,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual limit to time expiry; stretching to set-aside improper, contra High Court/Barangore.

holdings.text: Under Rule X, prior tribunal 'becomes incapable of acting' includes incapacity due to misconduct leading to award set aside; Registrar can appoint new tribunal to proceed de novo or on record.

anchor.surface_text: Rule X is in these terms- If any appointed arbitrator or umpire neglects or refuses to act or dies or become incapable of acting the Registrar shall substitute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide textual/purposive interpretation of 'incapable'; not limited to physical (contra dies proximity); analogy to interest acquisition; Russel on English s.10(b).

holdings.text: There was no misconduct by the second tribunal justifying setting aside the award dated March 15, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge relied on the decision in The Barangore Jute Factory  1  and held that from what that respondent said to the Chamber its letter of September 7, 1953,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Single Judge found no grounds; not challenged on appeal.

holdings.text: In appeal No.525, no arbitration agreement ceased to exist post-set aside without supersession; s.33 application fails for reasons in 309.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to appeal No. 525, it is enough to say that it is similar to appeal No. 309 in all respects except one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same analysis as appeal 309 applies; reference subsists.

holdings.text: Even assuming s.33 order not appealable under s.39 (point not raised earlier), Supreme Court would grant special leave to affirm High Court on merits; no technical bar.

anchor.surface_text: It has been contended on behalf of the appellant that the order under s. 33 was not appealable in view of the provisions of s. 39 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter: procedural technicality yields to merits; companion appeal supports.

anchor.surface_text: Morduse v. Palmer  1

precedents.cited_proposition: arbitrator functus officio after signing award and cannot alter even slightest error from clerk's mistake; proper course is to refer back
precedents.cited_holding: An arbitrator having signed his award is functus officio and cannot alter the slightest error in it, even though such error has arisen from the mistake of the clerk in copying the draft.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: No other point has been urged on behalf of the appellant in this appeal to challenge the companyrectness of the decision of the High Court. Therefore, appeal No. 309 must fail. Turning number to appeal No. 525, it is enough to say that it is similar to appeal No. 309 in all respects except one. The difference is that in this case the appellant objected to the appointment of a fresh tribunal and an application was made under s. 33 of the Act paying for the relief that numberarbitration agreement existed after the earlier award had been set aside and therefore there companyld be numberfurther arbitration.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals Nos. 309/59 and 525/59 dismissed; High Court orders upheld

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 reads as follows- Where an award has become void under sub-section 3  of section 16 or has been set aside, the court may by order supersede the reference and shall thereupon order that the arbitration agreement shall cease to have effect with respect to the difference referred.
